data.title: Chorus (2015)
data.meta_description: A separated couple meet again after 10 years when the body of their missing son is found. Amid the guilt of losing a loved one, they hesitantly move toward affirmation of life, acceptance of death, and even the possibility of reconciliation.
data.text:
It’s risky—and somewhat admirable—that François Delisle took a premise so easily rendered as melodrama and instead aimed for quiet restraint. Yet somewhere along that road, the restraint itself starts to feel like an affectation. The story concerns Irène (Fanny Mallette) and Christophe (Sébastien Ricard), a once-married couple separated for 10 years since the disappearance of their 8-year-old son, Hugo. But when someone finally confesses to Hugo’s murder, Irène and Christophe are reunited in Montreal in their attempt to find closure. François Delisle's (The Meteor) tale of grieving, separated parents finally faced with the undeniable truth of their young son's murder packs an understated emotional wallop even with its share of missteps along the way.

A decade after their son first went missing, former married couple Christophe (Sébastien Ricard) and Irene (Fanny Mallette) are reunited when a prisoner confesses to the murder and helps the authorities unearth the remains. With old feelings flaring up while each tries to cope with the new revelations, melancholy and joy intertwine in the most bittersweet of ways.
